head.title: North Carolina Wins Its 8th Title in a Row

hedline.hl1: North Carolina Wins Its 8th Title in a Row

block.p: The women's soccer team at the University of North Carolina captured its eighth consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association title yesterday with a 6-0 triumph over George Mason at Chapel Hill, N.C.
The game was played before a crowd of 5,721, the largest in the history of women's collegiate soccer.

The women's soccer team at the University of North Carolina captured its eighth consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association title yesterday with a 6-0 triumph over George Mason at Chapel Hill, N.C.
The game was played before a crowd of 5,721, the largest in the history of women's collegiate soccer.

The Tar Heels' victory yesterday was their 23d of the season and their 81st in a row. North Carolina has captured the title every year but one since the N.C.A.A. started the women's tournament in 1982.

George Mason, won the 1985 championship, but it couldn't keep up with the Tar Heels yesterday. Keri Sanchez opened the scoring with a goal less than two minutes into the game and Danielle Egan closed it with less than two minutes to go.

The men's Division I tournament completed its second round over the weekend and the University of Virginia, the champion the last two years, reached the quarterfinals with a 2-1 victory yesterday over Loyola of Baltimore in a game played in Charlottesville, Va.
Claudio Reyna, the best midfielder at the collegiate level, scored the winner for the Cavaliers with a blistering shot from 20 yards away with 8 minutes left.
Virginia's opponent in the quarterfinals will be Wisconsin, a 1-0 winner over Indiana yesterday in a game at Bloomington, Ind.

Hartwick College also reached the quarterfinals with a 2-1 overtime triumph over Boston University yesterday in Oneonta, N.Y., and will meet Princeton, a 5-2 winner over Penn State on Saturday. Ian McIntyre, the sweeper, scored the winner for Hartwick with 12 minutes left in the second overtime.
South Carolina reached the quarterfinals for the second time in four years with a 3-2 triumph at Clemson yesterday and will meet Air Force, a 2-1 winner over North Carolina.

The other quarterfinal will be between California-Fullerton, which won by 3-2 yesterday over the University of San Diego, last year's runner-up to Virginia, and San Francisco, a 2-1 winner over St. Louis in San Francisco Saturday night.
